docs.lead_paragraph: Alzheimer's remains a poorly understood disease, but one study suggests a possible link between it and early life. One of the University of Washington researchers involved in the study, Dr. Victoria M. Moceri, an epidemiologist who presented the research in the journal Neurology, said she was not claiming she had found the cause of the debilitating illness.
docs.abstract: Researchers speculate about whether some early childhood factors, like growing up in poverty, may be linked to developing Alzheimer's later on in life (S)
docs.snippet: Alzheimer's remains a poorly understood disease, but one study suggests a possible link between it and early life.    One of the University of Washington researchers involved in the study, Dr. Victoria M. Moceri, an epidemiologist who presented the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Children who show a propensity for extreme aggression at young ages often have low levels of a hormone produced by the body during times of fear or stress, researchers have found. Although the findings may appear counterintuitive, scientists at the University of Chicago Medical Center believe they may mean that some violent people simply experience less fear than normal people, leading to unchecked aggressiveness.
docs.abstract: Researchers find that children who show a propensity for extreme aggression at young ages often have low levels of a hormone produced by body during times of fear or stress (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Well, folks, the year 2000 is here and the bad news is that Americans failed to achieve many of the health goals established by the surgeon general in 1979 in an ambitious report called Healthy People 2000. Several of the societal goals, like improvements in maternal and child health and fewer deaths from breast cancer and heart disease, were met. But we fell sadly short on most of the objectives that are under personal control, like diet, exercise and cigarette smoking.

headline.main: On Health Report Card, the 'F' Stands for Fat

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on report that Americans failed to achieve many of health goals established by Surgeon General in 1979 in an ambitious report called Healthy People 2000; notes several of societal goals, like improvements in maternal and child health and fewer deaths from breast cancer and heart disease, were met; says Americans fells short on most of objectives that are under personal control, like diet, exercise and cigarette smoking; notes that new goals outlined in Healthy People 2010 issued by Dr David Satcher, Surgeon General; chart (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists may be no closer to explaining why the incidence of asthma has been escalating in the United States, but a new study confirms that a number of common indoor materials may be making the situation worse. The Institute of Medicine, part of the National Academy of Sciences, has issued a report agreeing with those who believe that factors like dust mites, secondhand smoke and allergens shed by pets can play a role in making asthma worse for those who are predisposed to the disease. The institute also recommended ways to limit the irritants.
docs.abstract: New study confirms that number of common indoor materials like dust mites may be aggravating problem of asthma (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A British medical journal has reported that Monday is the most common day for the Scots to suffer fatal heart attacks, and researchers believe that increased drinking during the weekend may explain the death rate. The Scottish scientists, who reported their findings in The British Medical Journal, recounted a study they made of coronary heart disease from 1986 to 1995, a period during which about 170,000 people died from the disease.

headline.main: A Darker Down Side for Mondays

docs.abstract: British medical journal reports that Monday is most common day for Scots to suffer fatal heart attacks, and researchers believe that increased drinking during weekend may explain death rate (S) y

docs.lead_paragraph: Ruth Arnold can recall a time when her memory was perfect. Years ago, working as a college reference librarian, she could put her finger on any piece of minutia at will. ''I remembered all the books and what was in them,'' Mrs. Arnold said. Now, at 81, she finds her memory fuzzy. ''I forget the hour of an appointment,'' she said. '' I forget who I'm going to see and what I'm going to tell them. I started out with a very good memory. It's a lot to lose.''

headline.main: Is Memory Loss Inevitable? Maybe Not

docs.abstract: Brain researchers study memory loss, with view to tracing memory loss in the aging process and developing treatments; studies have shown that more than a third of elderly can remember names and events in their lives as sharply as their 20-year-old counterparts, suggesting that memory loss is not necessarily inevitable; quiz shows guidelines for differentiating between age-related memory loss, and early Alzheimer's; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mentally ill people who have heart attacks are less likely to be offered the kind of treatment customarily available to other patients, a new study reports. In some cases, Yale researchers wrote in The Journal of the American Medical Association, patients with conditions like schizophrenia are 32 percent less likely to undergo cardiovascular procedures.

headline.main: For the Mentally Ill, a Gap in Cardiac Care

docs.abstract: New study finds that mentally ill people who have heart attacks are less likely to be offered kind of treatment customarily available to other patients (S)
docs.snippet: Mentally ill people who have heart attacks are less likely to be offered the kind of treatment customarily available to other patients, a new study reports.    In some cases, Yale researchers wrote in The Journal of the American Medical Association,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Asthma and infections like pneumonia and bronchitis accounted for more than half the hospitalizations of children from 1 to 4 years old in a major study of children's health in the United States. The research, the most comprehensive in a decade, also found that the conditions were responsible for nearly a third of hospital stays for 5- to 9-year-olds. Among 15- to 17-year-olds, 3 out of 10 hospitalizations were for pregnancy or childbirth. And for younger adolescents, depression and other mental disorders were the main diagnoses, accounting for more than 9 percent of hospital stays for 10- to 14-year-olds, compared with less than 2 percent for adults.

headline.main: Why Children End Up in the Hospital

docs.lead_paragraph: The case, Dr. Randolph M. Nesse said, does not fit tidily with the view that depression is only a matter of disordered brain chemicals: A woman sought help from a psychiatric clinic because she was desperately depressed. She had dedicated five years to becoming a professional musician, despite her teachers' admonitions that she lacked the talent to succeed. She persisted, the woman said, because it was her mother's dream for her.

headline.main: Viewing Depression As Tool for Survival

docs.abstract: Some psychiatrists view depression as an evolutionary tool for survival, which may have developed as a useful response to situations in which a desired goal is unattainable, or, as Dr Randolph M Nesse puts it, 'When one of life's paths peters out into the woods' (M)
